sn46.28:1.1.en: “Mendicants, I will teach you a path that helps penetration.

sn46.28:1.3.en: And what is the path that helps penetration?

sn46.28:1.9.pli: “kathaṁ bhāvitā nu kho, bhante, satta bojjhaṅgā kathaṁ bahulīkatā nibbedhāya saṁvattantī”ti?
sn46.28:1.9.en: “Sir, how are the seven awakening factors developed and cultivated so as to lead to penetration?”

sn46.28:2.9.pli: Evaṁ bhāvitā kho, udāyi, satta bojjhaṅgā evaṁ bahulīkatā nibbedhāya saṁvattantī”ti.
sn46.28:2.9.en: This is how are the seven awakening factors are developed and cultivated so as to lead to penetration.”

mlDocs.title:
Linked Discourses 46.28
3. With Udāyī
Helping Penetration

an4.179:2.1.pli: “Idhāvuso ānanda, sattā imā hānabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti, imā ṭhitibhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti, imā visesabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti, imā nibbedhabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānanti.
an4.179:2.1.en: “Reverend Ānanda, it’s because some sentient beings don’t really understand which perceptions make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration.

an4.179:3.2.pli: “Idhāvuso ānanda, sattā imā hānabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti, imā ṭhitibhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti, imā visesabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti, imā nibbedhabhāgiyā saññāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānanti.
an4.179:3.2.en: “Reverend Ānanda, it’s because some sentient beings truly understand which perceptions make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration.

an6.71:1.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘ime hānabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘ime ṭhitibhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘ime visesabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ‘ime nibbedhabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, asakkaccakārī ca hoti, asappāyakārī ca.
an6.71:1.3.en: It’s when a mendicant doesn’t truly understand which qualities make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration. And they don’t practice carefully or do what’s suitable.

an6.71:2.3.pli: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ‘ime hānabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ime ṭhitibhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ime visesabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ime nibbedhabhāgiyā dhammā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, sakkaccakārī ca hoti, sappāyakārī ca.
an6.71:2.3.en: It’s when a mendicant truly understands which qualities make things worse, which keep things steady, which lead to distinction, and which lead to penetration. And they practice carefully and do what’s suitable.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 6.71
7. A God
Capable of Realizing

an1.175-186:1.1.pli: “Ekapuggalassa, bhikkhave, pātubhāvā mahato cakkhussa pātubhāvo hoti, mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti, mahato obhāsassa pātubhāvo hoti, channaṁ anuttariyānaṁ pātubhāvo hoti, catunnaṁ paṭisambhidānaṁ sacchikiriyā hoti, anekadhātupaṭivedho hoti, nānādhātupaṭivedho hoti, vijjāvimuttiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, arahattaphalasacchikiriyā hoti.
an1.175-186:1.1.en: “With the appearance of one person, mendicants, there is the appearance of a great eye, a great light, a great radiance, and the six unsurpassable things; the realization of the four kinds of textual analysis; the penetration of many and diverse elements; the realization of the fruit of knowledge and freedom; the realization of the fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.

an1.175-186:1.4.pli: Imassa kho, bhikkhave, ekapuggalassa pātubhāvā mahato cakkhussa pātubhāvo hoti, mahato ālokassa pātubhāvo hoti, mahato obhāsassa pātubhāvo hoti, channaṁ anuttariyānaṁ pātubhāvo hoti, catunnaṁ paṭisambhidānaṁ sacchikiriyā hoti, anekadhātupaṭivedho hoti, nānādhātupaṭivedho hoti, vijjāvimuttiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, sakadāgāmiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, anāgāmiphalasacchikiriyā hoti, arahattaphalasacchikiriyā hotī”ti.
an1.175-186:1.4.en: This is the one person whose appearance brings the appearance of a great eye, a great light, a great radiance, and the six unsurpassable things; the realization of the four kinds of textual analysis; the penetration of many and diverse elements; the realization of the fruit of knowledge and release; the realization of the fruits of stream-entry, once-return, non-return, and perfection.”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 1.170–187
The Chapter on One Person

an1.593-595:1.1.pli: “Ekadhamme, bhikkhave, bhāvite bahulīkate anekadhātupaṭivedho hoti … nānādhātupaṭivedho hoti … anekadhātupaṭisambhidā hoti.
an1.593-595:1.1.en: “When one thing is developed and cultivated there is the penetration of many elements … the penetration of diverse elements … the analysis of many elements.

an1.593-595:1.4.pli: Imasmiṁ kho, bhikkhave, ekadhamme bhāvite bahulīkate anekadhātupaṭivedho hoti … nānādhātupaṭivedho hoti … anekadhātupaṭisambhidā hotī”ti.
an1.593-595:1.4.en: When this one thing is developed and cultivated there is the penetration of many elements … the penetration of diverse elements … the analysis of many elements.”

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 1.575–615
The Chapter on Mindfulness of the Body

So It Was Said 41
The Book of the Twos
Chapter Two
Bereft of Wisdom

So It Was Said 93
The Book of the Threes
Chapter Five
Fire

an6.29:10.2.pli: Idaṁ, bhante, anussatiṭṭhānaṁ evaṁ bhāvitaṁ evaṁ bahulīkataṁ anekadhātupaṭivedhāya saṁvattati.
an6.29:10.2.en: When this topic of recollection is developed and cultivated in this way it leads to the penetration of many elements.

mlDocs.title:
Verses of the Senior Monks 10.7
The Book of the Tens
Chapter One
Another Gotama

an8.20:9.4.pli: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye anupubbasikkhā anupubbakiriyā anupubbapaṭipadā, na āyatakeneva aññāpaṭivedho.
an8.20:9.4.en: In the same way in this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 8.20
2. The Great Chapter
Sabbath

an8.19:10.7.pli: evamevaṁ kho, pahārāda, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye anupubbasikkhā anupubbakiriyā anupubbapaṭipadā, na āyatakeneva aññāpaṭivedho.
an8.19:10.7.en: In the same way in this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 8.19
2. The Great Chapter
With Pahārāda

an9.36:10.1.pli: Iti kho, bhikkhave, yāvatā saññāsamāpatti tāvatā aññāpaṭivedho.
an9.36:10.1.en: And so, mendicants, penetration to enlightenment extends as far as attainments with perception.

mlDocs.title:
Numbered Discourses 9.36
4. The Great Chapter
Depending on Absorption

ud5.5:19.2.pli: evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, imasmiṁ dhammavinaye anupubbasikkhā anupubbakiriyā anupubbapaṭipadā, na āyatakeneva aññāpaṭivedho.
ud5.5:19.2.en: In the same way in this teaching and training the penetration to enlightenment comes from gradual training, progress, and practice, not abruptly.

mn73:18.2.pli: Ime kho te, vaccha, dve dhammā uttari bhāvitā—samatho ca vipassanā ca—anekadhātupaṭivedhāya saṁvattissanti.
mn73:18.2.en: When you have further developed these two things, they’ll lead to the penetration of many elements.

mlDocs.title:
Middle Discourses 73
The Longer Discourse With Vacchagotta

dn34:1.5.31.pli: hānabhāgiyo samādhi, ṭhitibhāgiyo samādhi, visesabhāgiyo samādhi, nibbedhabhāgiyo samādhi.
dn34:1.5.31.en: immersion liable to decline, stable immersion, immersion that leads to distinction, and immersion that leads to penetration.
